summary: This is a Department of Justice Morning News Digest for July 7, 2020, summarizing major news headlines from the previous day. It covers a wide range of topics including COVID-19, federal law enforcement activities, national security, immigration, Supreme Court rulings, and criminal law cases. A notable item reports on the transfer of Ghislaine Maxwell to a federal detention center in Brooklyn.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as the longtime companion of Jeffrey Epstein, accused of facilitating his sexual abuse of teenage girls. The digest reports she was transferred to a federal detention center in Brooklyn ahead of an arraignment and bail hearing.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the sex offender whose abuse Ghislaine Maxwell is accused of facilitating.

persons.name: David Muir
persons.context: Anchor of ABC's 'World News Tonight', listed in the network evening news lineup.

persons.name: Norah O'Donnell
persons.context: Anchor of CBS's 'Evening News', listed in the network evening news lineup.

persons.name: Lester Holt
persons.context: Anchor of NBC's 'Nightly News', listed in the network evening news lineup.

persons.name: Anthony Fauci
persons.context: The nation's top infectious disease expert, quoted as saying the status of the coronavirus pandemic in the US is 'really not good'.

persons.name: Keisha Lance Bottoms
persons.context: Announced she tested positive for the coronavirus.

persons.name: Bubba Wallace
persons.context: NASCAR's only African American driver, whom President Trump demanded an apology from after the FBI determined he was not a target of a hate crime.

persons.name: Vanessa Guillen
persons.context: A soldier whose disappearance and death at Fort Hood is mentioned; a woman was charged in connection with the case.

persons.name: Cecily Aguilar
persons.context: A Texas woman charged with conspiracy to tamper with evidence in the disappearance and death of U.S. Army Spc. Vanessa Guillen. She appeared in court virtually.

persons.name: Jeffrey C. Manske
persons.context: The judge before whom Cecily Aguilar appeared virtually.

persons.name: Elizabeth Jo Shirley
persons.context: A West Virginia woman convicted in a plot to offer top-secret NSA information to Russia.

persons.name: Paul Erickson
persons.context: A man romantically linked to a Russian spy, sentenced to seven years in a fraud case.

persons.name: Elena Kagan
persons.context: Wrote the Supreme Court's unanimous opinion that a state may require presidential electors to support the winner of its popular vote.

persons.name: Brett Kavanaugh
persons.context: Wrote the court's controlling opinion in a case that broadened the federal ban on robocalls to mobile phones.

persons.name: Dogar Singh
persons.context: A New Jersey man charged in Maryland with participating in a bank fraud scheme.

persons.name: Rehan Afridi
persons.context: A New Jersey man charged in Maryland with participating in a bank fraud scheme.

persons.name: Elston Stevenson
persons.context: A man sentenced for shooting into the open grave of a murdered man.

persons.name: John J. Tharp, Jr.
persons.context: Sentenced Elston Stevenson.

persons.name: Rowan M. Olsen
persons.context: Faces allegations related to unrest at a federal courthouse in Portland.

persons.name: Ashraf Omar Eldarir
persons.context: A Brooklyn man indicted for allegedly trying to smuggle Egyptian artifacts through JFK Airport.

persons.name: H. David Derby
persons.context: A man from Dubuque sentenced to federal prison for fraud related to money taken from his mother.

persons.name: Patti Lynn Derby
persons.context: A woman from Dubuque sentenced to federal prison for fraud related to money taken from her mother-in-law.

persons.name: Larry Ray Bon
persons.context: A double-amputee veteran sentenced for opening fire at a VA Medical Center.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: Ordered the sentence for Larry Ray Bon.

persons.name: Joshua Kevin Laxton
persons.context: A man sentenced for trying to have sex with a minor.

persons.name: Paul Belloisi
persons.context: An American Airlines mechanic accused of smuggling cocaine.

persons.name: John Wilson
persons.context: A parent charged in the 'Varsity Blues' college admissions case.

persons.name: William 'Rick' Singer
persons.context: The mastermind of the 'Varsity Blues' college admissions scheme.

persons.name: Nathaniel M. Gorton
persons.context: Denied John Wilson's request in the 'Varsity Blues' case.

persons.name: Michael Avenatti
persons.context: An embattled attorney whose temporary release from prison was extended ahead of an embezzlement trial.

persons.name: James Selna
persons.context: Extended Michael Avenatti's temporary release.

persons.name: Ali Abbas
persons.context: Charged in a bank fraud conspiracy in New Jersey.

persons.name: Habib Majid
persons.context: Charged in a bank fraud conspiracy in New Jersey.

persons.name: Naveed Arif
persons.context: Charged in a bank fraud conspiracy in New Jersey.

persons.name: Craig Carpenito
persons.context: Announced the bank fraud conspiracy charges.

persons.name: Erick Bautista Irias-Zepeda
persons.context: A Honduran citizen sentenced for being an illegal alien in possession of a firearm.

persons.name: Michael J. Juneau
persons.context: Sentenced Erick Bautista Irias-Zepeda.

persons.name: Daniel Davis
persons.context: A former Angola guard sentenced for beating a handcuffed inmate and conspiring to cover it up.

persons.name: Roger Stone
persons.context: His lawyers asked an appeals court to delay the start of his prison sentence.

persons.name: Jonathan Sackler
persons.context: One of the owners of OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma, whose death was reported.

persons.name: Raymond Sackler
persons.context: Father of Jonathan Sackler, one of the brothers who bought the company that became Purdue Pharma.

persons.name: Jim Jordan
persons.context: The top Republican on the House Judiciary Committee, seeking information about the sentencing of Roger Stone.

persons.name: Chuck Grassley
persons.context: Senate Finance Committee Chairman who commented on the timing of potential prosecutions from John Durham's probe.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to the Durham probe and the scheduling of federal executions.

persons.name: John Durham
persons.context: Leading a probe into FBI and CIA misconduct related to the Trump campaign.

persons.name: Daniel Lewis Lee
persons.context: A prisoner set to be the first executed by the federal government in 17 years.

connections.description: Described as the 'longtime companion' of Jeffrey Epstein, accused of facilitating his sexual abuse.
Aguilar is charged in connection with the disappearance and death of U.S. Army Spc. Vanessa Guillen.
Wilson is a parent charged in the 'Varsity Blues' college admissions scheme orchestrated by Singer.
Jonathan Sackler was the son of Raymond Sackler, co-founder of Purdue Pharma.
Rep. Jim Jordan is seeking information related to the sentencing of Trump associate Roger Stone.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Transferred to Brooklyn
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was transferred from New Hampshire to the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, New York, ahead of an arraignment and bail hearing.

events.title: Court Appearance in Vanessa Guillen Case
events.description: Cecily Aguilar, charged in the disappearance and death of U.S. Army Spc. Vanessa Guillen, appeared virtually in court before U.S. Magistrate Judge Jeffrey C. Manske.

events.title: Supreme Court Rules on Faithless Electors
events.description: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a state may require presidential electors to support the winner of its popular vote.

events.title: Scheduled Federal Execution
events.description: Daniel Lewis Lee is scheduled to be the first prisoner executed by the federal government in 17 years.

events.title: Death of Jonathan Sackler
events.description: Jonathan Sackler, co-owner of OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma, died of cancer.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell, accused of facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse, was transferred to a federal detention center in Brooklyn on July 6, 2020.
The document is a DOJ news digest covering a wide array of topics from July 6, 2020, indicating the breadth of issues the department monitors.
A significant portion of the digest covers non-Epstein related criminal and civil legal news, Supreme Court rulings, and COVID-19 updates.
The digest reports on the death of Jonathan Sackler, a co-owner of Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin.
It notes the upcoming federal executions scheduled to resume in July 2020 after a 17-year hiatus.
